Introduction

Restless leg syndrome (RLS) is a common neurologic sensorimotor disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move the legs that is often accompanied by dysesthesia (eg, itching, crawling sensation).  Symptoms occur primarily at rest and at night and can be temporarily relieved by movement.  RLS commonly disrupts sleep and can significantly impair quality of life.  The incidence increases with age, with up to 25% of the population age >65 affected by RLS.

Pathophysiology

RLS is classified as primary (if idiopathic) or secondary (if accompanied by a predisposing condition or caused by medications listed in the "Risk factors" section).  Nearly half of patients with idiopathic RLS have a positive family history (autosomal dominant inheritance).

The pathophysiology of RLS is not clearly understood, but it is associated with central nervous system (CNS) and peripheral nervous system abnormalities:

  • CNS findings include reduced iron stores and dysfunction of dopaminergic and other neurotransmitter (eg, glutamate, histamine) pathways (some of which are close to the circadian control centers).
  • Peripheral abnormalities include hyperalgesia and sensitization of afferent pain nerves partly mediated by A-delta fiber input.

Risk factors

  • Family history:  Most patients have a positive family history, with patterns suggesting an autosomal dominant transmission.
  • Iron deficiency:  Given that RLS is associated with low CNS iron stores, low total body iron stores also increases the risk of RLS.
  • Chronic conditions:
    • Uremia (eg, end-stage renal disease)
    • Neuropathy (eg, diabetes mellitus, alcohol-associated)
    • Spinal cord disease (eg, trauma, demyelinating conditions), multiple sclerosis, Parkinson disease
  • Medications:  Dopamine antagonists (eg, antipsychotics, certain antiemetics [metoclopramide]), first-generation antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine), and antidepressants (eg, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors [eg, sertraline], mirtazapine), can precipitate or worsen RLS.
  • Pregnancy:  RLS affects 20% of pregnant patients in Western countries.

Clinical presentation

RLS is characterized by the following features:

  • An irresistible urge to move the legs, often accompanied by dysesthesia (eg, itching, crawling, tingling, restless sensation).
  • Symptoms begin or worsen at rest (eg, sitting, lying down).
  • Symptoms worsen or occur exclusively at night.
  • Symptoms abate with movement (eg, walking, stretching).

The dysesthesia is typically experienced between the knee and ankle and is often described as a sensation deep inside the leg.  Although RLS primarily affects the legs, it can also affect the arms.  RLS does not cause pain or neurologic deficits (eg, numbness, weakness).  Symptom severity and frequency vary among patients.

Diagnosis

The diagnosis of RLS is made clinically based on the clinical features listed above.  In addition, another cause of these symptoms (eg, venous stasis, leg edema, myalgia) should be excluded before the diagnosis of RLS is made.

Laboratory evaluation

Laboratory evaluation is aimed primarily at identifying iron deficiency, which is often clinically silent, unlike other secondary causes of RLS that typically have overt symptoms (eg, pregnancy, Parkinson disease, end-stage renal disease).  Therefore, iron studies (eg, ferritin, total iron binding capacity, serum iron) should be obtained.  A normal complete blood count is insufficient because iron deficiency can exist without anemia.

Additional studies to consider may vary based on clinical presentation (eg, polysomnography to rule out obstructive sleep apnea when daytime sleepiness is present, nerve conduction velocities/electromyogram to distinguish neuropathy from RLS when unclear clinically).

Differential diagnosis

  • Periodic limb movement disorder (PLMD):  Presents with periodic (eg, every 20-40 seconds) involuntary limb twitches or jerks during sleep.  These movements are followed by brief awakenings that patients are unaware of, leading to daytime sleepiness.    Unlike with RLS, patients typically do not experience sensory discomfort.  Although RLS is often accompanied by periodic limb movements during sleep, PLMD is only diagnosed if it is not caused by another sleep disorder or RLS.
  • Peripheral artery disease (PAD):  Presents with lower extremity muscle pain that worsens with exercise and subsides with rest (intermittent claudication), a pattern that is contrary to that of RLS.  PAD also can be associated with skin atrophy, hair loss, and ulcers, which are absent in RLS.
  • Chronic venous insufficiency:  Can present with aching or a heavy feeling in the legs associated with swelling and skin changes (eg, dermatitis, ulceration).  In contrast to RLS, pain increases when walking and improves when lying down (due to gravity assisting with venous drainage).
  • Peripheral neuropathy (eg, diabetic):  Classically manifests with decreased sensation or burning pain in a stocking-glove distribution.
  • Nocturnal leg cramps:  Present with sudden, painful tightness of the calf muscles with obvious muscle hardening, not present in RLS.  In addition, relief typically requires stretching of the muscle rather than continuous movement.
  • Akathisia:  Typically associated with dopamine-blocking drugs (eg, antipsychotics) and causes a generalized inner restlessness and an impulse to move, rather than a restlessness limited to the legs.  Akathisia is not accompanied by dysesthesia (eg, tingling, crawling sensation, itching) often seen in RLS.
  • Positional leg discomfort:  Results from sitting or lying in the same position for a long time and is relieved by change of position.  It does not require continuous movement to maintain relief.  It is also not associated with exacerbations in the evening, as seen in RLS.

Management

Management consists of nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic therapy.

All patients should undergo nonpharmacologic therapy, with iron supplementation indicated for those with ferritin levels â‰¤75 ng/mL.  These measures may sufficiently control symptoms that are intermittent (eg, <2 times a week) and mild.  Pharmacologic therapy is reserved for patients with frequent/daily symptoms or patients with intermittent symptoms recalcitrant to nonpharmacologic therapy.

Nonpharmacologic therapy 

  • Avoid caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine.
  • Maintain sleep hygiene, and engage in regular exercise.
  • Try leg massages or warm/cold soaks or compresses.
  • Stop culprit medications (eg, glucocorticoids, calcium channel blockers, phenytoin, lithium, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors).

Pharmacologic therapy 

  • Gabapentin or pregabalin are taken on a daily basis and are recommended for chronic, persistent symptoms.  They are alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands that affect A-delta fibers, inhibit calcium influx, and blunt neurotransmitter release.  The exact mechanism in improving RLS symptoms is unknown.

For patients with intermittent symptoms (eg, <2 times a week) recalcitrant to nonpharmacologic therapy, carbidopa-levodopa increases dopamine levels in the CNS (

) and may be considered on an as-needed basis.  Dopaminergic agents (eg, pramipexole or ropinirole) are no longer recommended as initial therapy for chronic, persistent symptoms.  With daily, long-term therapy, they can cause symptom augmentation (ie, paradoxical worsening).

Complications

  • Sleep disturbance:  Nighttime symptoms can make it difficult to fall or stay asleep, resulting in fatigue, mood disturbances, cognitive impairment, and daytime sleepiness.
  • Psychologic effects:  Depression and anxiety are common due to impaired quality of life.
  • Medication adverse effects:  Long-term use of dopaminergic agents may lead to augmentation, where symptoms worsen or spread to other body parts.  Therefore, gabapentin or pregabalin are usually preferred.

Prognosis

RLS is a chronic condition with variable severity.  Many patients experience symptom relief with appropriate treatment, but relapses are common.  Secondary RLS caused by reversible conditions, such as iron deficiency or pregnancy, typically resolves once the underlying cause is addressed.

Special considerations:  Pregnancy

RLS in pregnancy typically worsens throughout gestation and improves or resolves after delivery.  However, women who have RLS during pregnancy are at increased risk of developing primary (idiopathic) RLS in the future.

As in other patients with RLS, serum iron studies should be obtained, and supplementation should be initiated for ferritin levels â‰¤75 ng/mL.  Sleep hygiene and gentle exercise should be recommended as well as reassurance of the likely temporary nature of symptoms.  Other agents typically used in RLS (eg, alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands [eg, gabapentin, pregabalin]) should be avoided in pregnancy.
